Header: Sri Lanka and Norway to take a new path
Content: Prime Minister Ranil Wickremasinghe and Norwegian Prime Minister Erna Solberg has emphasized that relations between the two countries should be directed on a new path. Prime Minister Ranil Wickremasinghe met the Norwegian Prime Minister in Oslo. The Norwegian Prime Minister said that there should be a common program to protect and develop ocean resources as well as to share new knowledge with Sri Lanka. The two countries have signed agreements and ratified conventions to protect peace, democracy and human rights. The Norwegian Prime Minister said that both countries should be committed to protect them. Prime Minister Ranil Wickremasinghe pledged to give Sri Lanka’s full support to the Norway’s hope on making Arctic Ocean zone, a peaceful zone with new inventions and sustainable development. Thereafter Prime Minister Ranil Wickremasinghe held a discussion with the President of the Norwegian legislature, the Storting, Tone Wilhelmeseri Troen. She praised the Sri Lanka government for introducing laws with the intension of increasing women’s representation in politics. She inquired from the Prime Minister about the education system in Sri Lanka. The Prime Minister explained to her the programs which are underway to establish a quality educational system. He said that steps have been taken to meet the future aspirations of the students who leave the school after GCE O/L Examination, based on mandatory period of 13 years of education. Minister Vijith Wijayamuni Soysa, MPs Hesha Withanage, Kavinda Jayawardena, Prof. Maithri Wickremasinghe, Sri Lankan Ambassador in Norway Arusha Cooray, Prime Minister’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake, Prime Minister’s Additional Secretary Saman Athudahetti and the Prime Minister’s Special Assistant Sandra Perera were present on the occasion.
